Replies.Reply: The war ended three years ago, boy!
You mean those pure breds he just bought?
Ethan, countin' on you to look after things while I'm gone.
Mind you sweep up them shavin's.

He is walking through the scrub and brush grass, every sense alive and straining. He pauses every three or four strides -- casting each quadrant in turn. Once he whips, gun ready, as a sage-hen or quail whirrs up not far from him. He smiles grimly as he watches it fly away. He keeps on.
Lucy, you ain't much bigger than when I saw you last.
You askin' me to clear out now?
You were always hurting about your hands.
You askin' as a Reverend or a Captain, Sam?
I'd be obliged if you'd get to the point, ma'am.
You can back out any time, Nesby.
Why don't you finish the job?
They're camped by the river -- 'bout twenty miles from here.  Soon's it gets dark we'll circle out so's to jump 'em before daybreak.
It's what we're here for, ain't it?
You got any more orders, Captain?
If you were tryin' to surround 'em, you sure succeeded.
I still got one out there.
They're with 'em -- if they're still alive.
You got my letter about your son, Brad?
Scar? Never heard of any Chief Scar.
Whyn't you bed down closer to the fire, boy?
Replies.Didascalie: (he picks up a saddle and puts it close to fire)

Replies.Reply: You all settled an' comfortable now?
When are you goin' to learn to keep your mouth shut! Come on.  Let's get out of here.
YOU don't understand, ya chunkhead! You didn't buy any blanket! Ya bought her!
You got yourself a wife, sonny!
I got another gal purtier'n you.  I got another gal purtier'n you.  I got another gal purtier'n you.  Skip to my Lou, my darlin'.
Are you sure they didn't die of carbine shots fired by a bunch o' Yank bluebellies so scared they couldn't tell the difference between a Cheyenne and a Comanche?
Well, we only got the one lead --
How? She's even forgot her own language!
Your people? They murdered your family!
What's that got to do with us?
She's not a little girl any more.
This an invite to a necktie party, Reverend?
You don't remember it, but I remember. That was your mother's scalp!
Let's enjoy the dusk a while.
And you'll go along the ditch --
But I've got to help with the dishes.
She don't wear it much account of it makes her neck green.
Martin! Ride me as far as the well!
Can't I have Topsy to keep me company?
An' she's got a beau! Kisses him, too!
Did you kill many damYankees with this sabre, Uncle Ethan?
Will you tell me tomorrow about the war?
I wish Uncle Ethan was here. Don't you, ma?
I'll take care of your horse for you, Uncle Ethan.
What you want me to call you?
And you think we got a chance to find her?
Might at least have left me my pants!
That's what scares me -- him findin' her.
I gotta catch up with him, Laurie!
But that's Sweet-face -- your own good horse.
But I just bought a good blanket.
Think she means for us to follow?
You figger Scar means to kill us?
Why didn't he make his move back there?
Debbie, you're comin' with us!  Hear me?
I ain't goin' to Austin, Reverend.
Wait a minute! Isn't that the Caddo name for where all those canyons branch on the Malapai?

He is staring at it -- remembering it from certain distinct decorations. The lower part of the tepee is rolled up, for better air circulation. Martin wraps Charlie's blanket around him and begins walking to the tepee.
Haven't seen you since the surrender.
Come to think of it, I didn't see you at the surrender.
I'm askin' as a Ranger of the sovereign state of Texas.
You fit a lot of descriptions.
Looks like I'll be reading the lines over that pair before long, sister Edwards.
Well, that's seven we can score up to your brother, Ethan.
You're right sure you want to jump 'em, Ethan?
How far's the river from here, Mose?
I didn't give any order to fire!
Is this in the line of duty, sergeant?
I got to ask you and Martin to ride to the State Capitol with me, Ethan.
Kinda late getting here, aren't they?
And what makes you think he's in this territory?
Now son, it's a bitter thing to say, but there's more than your sister at stake here.
Go on! Whyn't you have your bugler sound the charge while you're at it??
Next time I raise pigs, by golly! You never hear of anyone running off pigs, I bet you.
Is no time for kaffee-klatch while a man's beef is been run off.
Ethan is about to mount when Mrs. Jorgensen comes up and catches his arm.
Who cares what he spells it? Read the letter.
That means Mister Futterman is dead, by golly.
Good! A young man should get married early in life. Right, mama?
Respects to a charmin' lady, ma'am.
as Jorgensen digs spurs and leads the way. The other riders follow.
as it comes up the rise and the men rein in on the crest.
Was there water in that canyon?
He comes pounding down a slope, and he takes off his hat and skims it away. He rips off a neckerchief as though to relieve the rush of raging blood.
Debbie sits on the floor, playing with a little rag doll.
Aaron is slowly scanning the terrain.

Aaron is little more than a shadowy silhouette as he peers into the night through a partly-opened shutter. Suddenly the room leaps alight as Lucy opens an inner door and enters, holding a lighted lamp. Aaron closes the shutter, spins on her angrily.
This 'un come a long way 'fore he died.
Reckon we got to go back -- Ed's shoulder is smashed -- bad!
I'll thank you to leave the room, Laurie.

Fog and heavy morning mist rise from the swamp. Some cattails in the near ground. The effect is eerie, very still except for the trilling of frogs. Then, very quietly, the men emerge from the mist swirling around them. They are leading their horses. Sam looks baffled, angry. They stand still, listening -- then slowly continue.

The mist is thinning. In the f.g. is a small blackened area -- the ashes of a campfire. The men come through the mist -- wary, vigilant. It is Mose who first spots the fire. He runs to it and drops beside and feels the ashes.
Ethan and Mose are hunkered down behind some rocks, very casual and business-like as they check rifles, set out and carefully wipe cartridges.
It is a portrait study of two faces -- etched by wind and privation and cold into tragic, fanatic masks.

The door is opened by a guard and Ethan takes a step into the room -- then stops in manifest shock. Martin  is at his heels, eager and expectant. Beyond them stands Keefer, grave and compassionate. There is a keening sound in the room -- almost an animal sound.
Emilio is standing near his horse, talking to Ethan and Martin.

He is in a rocker on the porch. Suddenly he stares out and stops rocking. Faint in the distance, but coming closer, the clop-clop of two horses, moving at a walk. A moment later Jorgensen emerges and comes to stand beside Mose, shading his eyes and squinting against the sun, still not recognizing the distant horsemen.  He is joined by Mrs. Jorgensen. And then Laurie comes out and she too stares, frowning at first, then with dawning realization.
The time is spring. It is a year and a half later.
leading their pack animals. Martin's voice picks up the narration.

yours truly, Martin Paulie.'  That's all there is. Not a cross on it. Laurie just looks at it. Jorgensen stands, pocketing his pipe, easing the crick in his back. He ceremoniously removes the spectacles and replaces them on the mantel.
I don't care if he never comes back!
It isn't fair, Martin Pauley, and you know it!
This is a room off the kitchen end of the keeping room --

She is in a robe made of an Indian blanket, belted snugly around her waist. She wears moccasins for slippers. Her flannel nightgown is high at the collar and almost trails the floor. She is at the stove, frying bacon and eggs; a coffee pot is on the boil. Beyond her the door to the grandmother room opens and Martin comes in -- dressed in Brad's clothes. His eyes whip around the room. Laurie doesn't turn as he slowly approaches.
ANGLING from behind Laurie in the doorway as Martin, riding one horse, leading another, goes galloping away.
It is the same scene the following morning. The men are standing above where Look had bedded for the night, looking at the ground. Clearly marked on the hard ground is a crudely drawn arrow.
You said there'd be a thousand dollar reward.
In that case you won't find her --
Don't forget to come back with my thousand dollars.
Three shadowy figures -- Futterman and his two henchmen -- are quietly dismounting, taking rifles from saddle scabbards.

The camp is on the outskirts of a trading post. Indians watch unsmilingly from tepees, or in little clusters afoot; a few mounted braves ride on parallel courses as Ethan and Martin ride through camp toward the post.

As the Indian proudly steps back, we see beyond him a half dozen other braves -- all rosetted. Ethan looks them over complacently while Martin -- to hide the smile that threatens to split his face -- bends to pick up a huge bundle of furs.
It was all over long before we got there and the soldiers was high-
as they ride in, passing dead horses, a few bodies of men.
The search theme is heard again as the two riders, with single pack horse, are heading south through New Mexico.

Their faces are sun-tanned, burned dark and dry. Gone are the heavy coats and clothing of their northern days. They do not speak, just ride -- and there is the same bleak, fanatic, hard look about them both. The music theme segues into something livelier and Mexican as we -

They are turning a bend and now, ahead, we see a cordon of Comanches -- all armed, all quiet, all very menacing as they watch the approaching column. Emilio calls a greeting in Comanche. It gets no answer.
They swing around giant boulders, up-ended like pancakes.
reading the letter. She is at the bottom of a page.
"LOOK" is somewhat under five feet tall, pigeon-toed, platter-
who rides in slowly, leading their pack horse and Martin's horse.
.  Martin looks blank, but Ethan chuckles.
Replies.Didascalie: (My father calls me Wild Goose Flying in the Night Sky... but you call me 'Look')

Replies.Reply: Just get him out of here!
Four to one! What did you do, general?
How do you spell that word -- Nawyecka?
Shall I show him the captives, sir?
Was your niece about their age?

Laurie has reached the last page of the letter, reading it by the lamp on the table. Jorgensen is knocking out the dead ashes of his pipe.  Charlie is in the shadows, a guitar in his hands -- not playing it, but occasionally softly picking a note or chord. Mrs. Jorgensen is dabbing moist eyes with a corner of her apron.
Scar looks at it greedily, then nods. He'll accept it.
Tomorrow -- manana -- 'puetze.'  Scar looks at Ethan and at Martin. He smiles slightly, and he nods his agreement.
Take it. I do not want blood money. Vaya con Dios!

winds through a canyon behind which we can see huge needles of rock: majestic, savage country. At the head of the column ride Ethan, Emilio, and Martin. Behind them come Emilio's cargadores -- lean, hard-bitten wiry little Mexicans. One leads a handsome palomino. The SOUND of the CASTANETS ECHOES in the musical theme.

Replies.Didascalie: (then he turns to the white men)

Replies.Reply: They are sitting with heads averted, slightly profiled -- but clearly Indian women, broad-faced, dark of hair and skin.
That maybe he's not far from here --
as she stands at the window, in her bridal gown, and sadly watches Martin again going away. Softly the score reprises -- sadly now -- "Skip to My Lou."
Scar isn't satisfied but returns to his work.
The line is drawn up, dismounted, the men checking their sidearms, tightening cinches, etc. Sam moves briskly along the line of men, then mounts his horse.
Clayton, if you were in my command I'd have you courtmartialed for this!

Ethan has Debbie on the pommel of his saddle, his arm supporting her, and she is asleep. Martin is riding beside them. Laurie comes running up to stare at Ethan and at the girl. He smiles and puts a finger to his lips -- cautioning her against waking Debbie -- and then he rides by. Laurie looks then at Martin. He doesn't know whether to smile or not; he just waits. And then she is beside him and she steps onto his stirruped foot and vaults up beside him, and she kisses him just as she had on the day he left the graves to take up the search. And still holding her beside him, he rides slowly after Ethan and Debbie toward the house.
